page.title: 15Local History
page.content: The Bronze and Iron Age Hillfort on Moel Hiraddug dominates the area. Nearby an important battle took place in 1034 between the sons of Edwin and Rhydderch.Later in 1241 Henry 3rd erected a castle soon destroyed by Prince Llywelyn ap Gruffudd in 1256. In 1263 Einion the second son of Rhodri Flaidd was killed during the seige of the castle.A standing stone commemorating this,was moved to the Parish Church dedicated to the two Celtic Saints Cwyfan and Bridget.The name Dyserth,probably comes from the Latin word"Deserta" which means a saint's cell in a lonely and deserted place.The Church also contains "The Jesse Window"removed from Basingwerk Abbey.Even the main Holywell to Rhyl Road is known in Dyserth as Ffordd Ffrainc,referring to the Norman Invasion route to Rhuddlan Castle.
